answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
See the attached document. We have our own Electric Utility and they do the work -- either on street lights or on a wire that runs across our Main Street. 
The policy is for the street banners that run across the street, the use of street light poles for other banners is very limited -- usually only 3-4 events per year are given that permission. Those are small banners that are placed on all the street lights on our Main St.

Hi John, 
You may find that Title 23 of the San Jose Municipal Code on sign ordinances is useful in determining how street light banners are used in your community. Information specific to different types of banners can be found on pages 10 and 31.

author: John Osborne
text:
Many communities have banners attached to streetlights. These banners may advertise a local community event or institution. Manatee County, FL is investigating the possibility of doing the same but is wondering what guiding policies other communities use.
We were considering a right-of-way use permit and maintenance agreement for the banners. Who pays for maintenance / installation? Who can use the brackets? Is it limited to use / language?
Any success with installing / cooperating with power company to mount on power poles?
In addition, we are looking for information on the specific hardware and any other obvious advice that could be provided. Thank you!
John Osborne, Planning Official
Manatee County, FL
title: Streetlight Banners
